working_definition: Traumatic Brain Injury is an acquired injury to the brain caused by an external physical force, resulting in total or partial functional disability or psychosocial impairment that adversely affects educational performance. It applies to open or closed head injuries resulting in impairments in one or more areas, including cognition, memory, attention, reasoning, abstract thinking, judgment, problem-solving, sensory, perceptual and motor abilities, psychosocial behavior, physical functions, information processing, and speech.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Concussion
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: A mild form of TBI that may cause temporary confusion, memory issues, and concentration problems.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Moderate to Severe TBI
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: Injuries that result in lasting cognitive, motor, or behavioral challenges requiring significant educational support.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Closed Head Injury
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: A brain injury where the skull remains intact, commonly caused by falls or car accidents.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Open Head Injury
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: A brain injury involving penetration of the skull, which may cause localized damage and recovery challenges.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Post-Concussive Syndrome
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: A cluster of symptoms including headaches, dizziness, and cognitive difficulties that persist after a concussion.

common_presentations: Impaired motor skills or physical coordination
Sensory sensitivities (e.g., to light or sound)
Problems with speech, language, or communication
Fatigue or reduced stamina throughout the school day
Inconsistent academic performance due to cognitive fluctuations

accommodations_modifications.name: Use of memory aids and checklists
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Supports recall of steps and routines
accommodations_modifications.example: Student uses a visual checklist for morning arrival tasks

accommodations_modifications.name: Shortened assignments with extended time
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Reduces cognitive load while allowing mastery
accommodations_modifications.example: Student completes 5 instead of 10 math problems with 50% extra time

accommodations_modifications.name: Extra wait time after questions or directions
accommodations_modifications.example: Teacher allows 10 seconds before expecting a verbal response

accommodations_modifications.name: Scheduled breaks for emotional regulation
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Helps manage behavioral or emotional fluctuations
accommodations_modifications.example: Student visits a quiet space when frustrated or overwhelmed

accommodations_modifications.name: Task segmentation with visual supports
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Supports task completion and reduces executive functioning load
accommodations_modifications.example: Student completes writing assignment in 3 separate guided steps

accommodations_modifications.name: Physical therapy and adapted physical education
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Improves motor planning and physical stamina
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Impaired motor skills or physical coordination
accommodations_modifications.example: Student participates in modified PE with individualized goals

accommodations_modifications.name: Reduced lighting and sound in learning spaces
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Sensory sensitivities (e.g., to light or sound)
accommodations_modifications.example: Student works in quiet area with dimmed lighting during tests

accommodations_modifications.name: Speech-language support for communication difficulties
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Improves expressive and receptive language skills
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Problems with speech, language, or communication
accommodations_modifications.example: Student receives 2 weekly speech sessions to work on sentence formation

accommodations_modifications.name: Energy management and reduced workload
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Prevents fatigue and supports sustained participation
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Fatigue or reduced stamina throughout the school day
accommodations_modifications.example: Student completes assignments in 15-minute blocks with breaks

accommodations_modifications.name: Frequent teacher check-ins to monitor performance
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Ensures consistency and support for fluctuating needs
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Inconsistent academic performance due to cognitive fluctuations
accommodations_modifications.example: Teacher reviews progress and adjusts tasks daily based on student’s alertness
